choices.text: A & D arises from same bony point.
C runs in between vein & nerve.
B is affected in this case due to which all symptoms appeared.
Arteria nervi ischiadici supplies B.

questions.text: A patient was presented with exacerbated chronic lower back pain in the sacral region with irradiation to the back of the left leg, producing a strong pain throbbing and burning behind the knee. Pain was aggravated when bending forward or in reaching out position. In his history he had a back condition from birth and later had an accident that resulted in fracture of the lumbar vertebrae. His MRI two months prior to this aggravation showed degeneration of L1, disc degeneration, and protrusion of the disc at the S1 level. He was prescribed strong non-steroid pain medication that made him feel drowsy but did not provide full pain relief. Seeking resolution for his pain he decided to try InterX therapy and treatment was aimed at whole Lumbar – Sacral zone, dermatomes L1 / L2 and L4, L5, S1 – S3, left buttock, right buttock, left back of the knee. After two and a half weeks use, he reported no pain, no discomfort, he stopped taking pain medication and started with the core exercise program to stabilize the lumbar spine. Advice to limit driving, prolong sitting, rest, good nutrition, and gentle stretching exercises. Six months of follow up confirmed that the patient still did not have pain, actively working and travelling. All the following anatomical statements are true about this case except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C runs in between vein & nerve.

 

 

This is a typical case of Sciatica.  Let’s break down each option:

  • Option A: A is long head of biceps femoris & D is semitendinosus which arises from same bony point known as ischial tuberosity. Hence it is true. 
  • Option B: C is popliteal vein which runs in between sciatic nerve / tibial nerve & popliteal artery. While in option it is given that popliteal vein runs in between vein & nerve, which is wrong statement.
  • Option C: B is sciatic nerve, which is affected in this case of sciatica. Hence it is true statement.
  • Option D: Arteria nervi ischiadici accompanies & supplies sciatic nerve . It is  branch of Inferior gluteal artery and it is remnant of axis artery of lower limb. That’s why it is also true statement.

 

Reference :

  • Gray’s Anatomy , International edition , 42nd edition , Page no. : 1339, 1392, 1393
  • A.K. Dutta, Essential of Human Anatomy , Volume 3, 4th edition , Page no. : 190

choices.text: Cerebral cortex
Cerebellum
Globus pallidus
Spinal cord

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a recent history of an abnormal gait characterized by cyclical flexion and extension motions of one leg during walking. There are no signs of upper limb involvement or cognitive impairment. The patient's muscle strength and sensation in both lower limbs are normal. Which level of the nervous system is most likely responsible for the observed gait abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Spinal cord

 

This gait abnormality is indicative of a pattern consistent with a spinal cord lesion or dysfunction. The spinal cord plays a crucial role in controlling rhythmic, coordinated movements, including walking. Flexion and extension of the legs during the gait cycle are controlled by central pattern generators (CPGs) located within the spinal cord. These CPGs generate the rhythmic motor patterns required for locomotion.

 

In this clinical case, the absence of upper limb involvement or cognitive impairment suggests that higher brain centers like the cerebral cortex and cerebellum are not primarily responsible.

 

The globus pallidus, part of the basal ganglia, is involved in motor control but is not directly responsible for generating the rhythmic leg movements seen during walking.

 

Therefore, a spinal cord lesion or dysfunction is the most likely cause of the abnormal gait pattern described. Further diagnostic evaluation and imaging may be needed to determine the exact location and nature of the spinal cord lesion.

choices.text: A emerges from nerve point behind the sternocleidomastoid, runs superiorly & divides into anterior & posterior division.
B is 1st branch of external carotid artery.
C is palpable along the lower margin of mandible in front of strongest muscle of body.
D is showing its activity under control of facial nerve.

questions.text: A patient got death due to malignant neck tumour. Neck dissection was done to know the extent of cancer for research purpose. All the following statements are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B is 1st branch of external carotid artery.

 

Let’s break down each option:

  • Option A: A is great auricular nerve which is main nerve supply of pinna. It emerges behind the sternocleidomastoid from nerve point then runs superiorly & divides into anterior & posterior division. Anterior division supplies the angle of mandible (shaving area) while posterior division supplies major part of pinna. Hence it is true. 
  • Option B: B is superior thyroid artery. It is the second branch of the external carotid artery not the 1st branch. That’s why it is wrong statement. 1st branch of ECA is ascending pharyngeal artery. The ascending pharyngeal artery is the only medial and smallest branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Option C: C is facial artery which is palpable along the lower margin of mandible in front of strongest muscle of body i.e. masseter. This option is also true.
  • Option D: D is submandibular gland. Secretion of this gland is control by facial nerve. That’s why it is also true statement.

 

 

 

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, International edition , 42nd edition , Page no. : 585

choices.text: A
B
C
D

questions.text: A 21-year-old null gravida caucasian patient presented with a 15-month history of amenorrhea, bifrontal headache, and photophobia. Examination revealed general physical, neurologic, and ophthalmoscopic findings with normal visual fields. A pelvic examination revealed normal external genitalia, nulliparous cervix and uterus, and bilateral cystic ovarian masses measuring 8 cm in diameter on the right and 4 cm on the left. Endocrine evaluation revealed an elevated serum prolactin in the range of 48 to 50 ng/ml. This situation was related with mass in the following area of the below image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B.

  • This is a case of galactorrhea amenorrhea syndrome, which occurs due to pituitary adenoma.
  • in case of pituitary adenoma lactotroph cells proliferate, which results in increase prolactin secretion.
  • Increase prolactin secretion leads to galactorrhea.  
  • Pituitary tumour also causes headache & visual symptoms because just above it optic chiasma located.
  • Pituitary gland is located in Sella turcia (Turkish saddle), which is shown by B in image.
  • Option A is cribriform plate of ethmoid which is related to 1st cranial nerve.
  • Option C is jugular foramen which is related to 9th , 10th  & 11th cranial nerves.
  • Option D is foramen magna which passes lower part of medulla oblongata.

 

 

 

Reference:

Gray’s Anatomy, International edition, 42nd edition , Page no. : 565

choices.text: Reabsorbed at a rate of 150 mg/min
Reabsorbed at a rate of 200 mg/min
Secreted at a rate of 50 mg/min
Secreted at a rate of 150 mg/min

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient undergoes renal function testing. The plasma concentration of a freely filterable substance is measured at 2 mg/mL. The patient's Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is determined to be 100 mL/min. Simultaneously, the urine concentration of the substance is found to be 10 mg/mL, and the urine flow rate is 5 mL/min. Based on these findings, what conclusion can be drawn about the handling of this substance by the kidney tubules?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Reabsorbed at a rate of 150 mg/min

 

To determine the rate of reabsorption or secretion of a substance by the kidney tubules, you can use the formula:

 

Rate = (Urine Concentration × Urine Flow Rate) - (Plasma Concentration × GFR)

 

In the case:

 

Urine Concentration = 10 mg/mL

 

Urine Flow Rate = 5 mL/min

 

Plasma Concentration = 2 mg/mL

 

GFR = 100 mL/min

 

Rate = (10 mg/mL × 5 mL/min) - (2 mg/mL × 100 mL/min)

 

Rate = (50 mg/min) - (200 mg/min)

 

Rate = -150 mg/min

 

A negative value indicates that the substance is being reabsorbed by the kidney tubules. Therefore, the substance is reabsorbed at a rate of 150 mg/min.

choices.text: The A doesn’t participate in formation of floor of anatomical snuff box.
The B is small and irregular bone with a rough palmar surface that is narrower and smaller than its rough dorsal surface.
The C is the largest carpal bone in the proximal carpal row. It has a long axis that is distal, radial and palmar in direction. In this case C is fractured where involvement of D also can be seen.
All are incorrect.

questions.text: An 18-year-old gymnast complained of insidious-onset and increasing right-wrist pain. He had been practicing gymnastics six hours a day, three days a week, for the past seven years. Approximately three months before his visit, he began to experience severe pain which worsened with wrist extension. Initially, he thought he had a muscle strain and treated it conservatively with ice packing and decreasing his activity level, but there was little improvement. On physical examination the patient had soft callus over the distal wrist.  He reported pain in the anatomic snuffbox and in distal radial epiphysis. Wrist extension was 38° on the right and 60° on the left. Patient’s range of motion was limited to 38° of extension and 12° of radial deviation on the right wrist but presented no flexion or ulnar deviation limitations. Pronation, supination, and digital motion were within normal limits. All of the following statements are correct regarding this case except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The A doesn’t participate in formation of floor of anatomical snuff box

 

This is the case of scaphoid fracture with distal radius involvement. This image is showing radiocarpal joint & carpal bones.

 

Let’s break down each option:

 

  • Option A: A is trapezium which forms the floor of anatomical snuff box. Hence statement given in this option is wrong.
  • Option B: B is trapezoid bone which is small and irregular bone. It has a rough palmar surface that is narrower and smaller than its rough dorsal surface. Hence this statement is true.
  • Option C: C is scaphoid bone which is most commonly fractured among the carpal bone.
    • Capitate is largest carpal bone but in proximal row scaphoid is largest carpal bone.
    • In this case scaphoid bone is fractured where involvement of distal radius can be seen.
    • It has a long axis that is distal, radial and palmar in direction.
       
  • Option D: Only option A is incorrect, rest all are correct. That’s why option D is not the answer. 

 

 

 

Reference :

Gray’s Anatomy , International edition , 42nd edition , Page no. : 961

choices.text: ICFV and ECFV will increase
ICFV and ECFV will decrease
ICFV will increase, and ECFV will decrease
ICFV will decrease, and ECFV will increase

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient's fluid balance is under evaluation. The patient's Intracellular Fluid Volume (ICFV) is measured at 28 liters, while the Extracellular Fluid Volume (ECFV) is measured at 14 liters, and the osmolarity is 300 milliosmoles/liter. The patient experiences a fluid loss of 2 liters from the ECF, with each liter containing 200 milliosmoles. In this clinical scenario, what is the most accurate statement regarding changes in fluid compartments?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ICFV and ECFV will decrease

 

When the subject loses 2 liters of ECF fluid, which contains 200 milliosmoles per liter, they lose both fluid and solutes (osmoles). This loss of solutes from the ECF will lead to water movement from the ICF to the ECF in an attempt to equalize osmolarity between the compartments. As a result:

 

ICFV will decrease as water moves from the intracellular compartment to the extracellular compartment to dilute the increased osmolarity in the ECF.

 

ECFV will also decrease due to the initial fluid loss and the movement of water out of the ECF into the ICF to restore osmotic balance.

choices.text: Cortical follicles
Medullary sinuses
Medullary cords
Paracortex region

questions.text: An infant is born with facial dysmorphia and a cleft palate. Further evaluation reveals a heart condition with a right-to-left shunt and the absence of a thymic shadow on x-ray. The infant experiences frequent and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Examination of this patient's lymph nodes will most likely show poor development of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Paracortex region

 

DiGeorge syndrome is caused by maldevelopment of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouch derivatives. Immunodeficiency can result from thymic aplasia, which leads to an extreme deficiency in the number of mature T Iymphocytes. Although T cells are synthesized in the bone marrow, they require processing in the thymus in order to mature and mount effective immune responses. Patients are thus predisposed to recurrent infections by viral, fungal, protozoan, and intracellular bacterial pathogens.

 

DiGeorge syndrome causes an extreme deficiency in the number of mature T lymphocytes, leading to poor development of the lymph node paracortex. In contrast, agammaglobulinemia causes an absence of B cells, preventing primary lymphoid follicles and germinal centers from forming in the lymph node cortex.

choices.text: The iron lung uses positive pressure to assist with inhalation and exhalation, enhancing oxygenation and CO2 removal.
The iron lung relies on negative pressure to create a vacuum around the patient's chest, promoting lung expansion and gas exchange.
The iron lung is equipped with advanced ventilator algorithms and real-time monitoring to adjust ventilation parameters automatically.
The iron lung stimulates the phrenic nerve through electrical impulses, restoring normal diaphragmatic function.

questions.text: An elderly patient is admitted to the hospital with a severe case of polio that has affected their respiratory muscles. Despite maximal medical therapy, the patient is experiencing significant respiratory distress and requires mechanical ventilation. Due to the patient's unique needs, the medical team decides to use an iron lung for respiratory support. Which of the following best describes the functioning principle of above given support system and its application in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The iron lung relies on negative pressure to create a vacuum around the patient's chest, promoting lung expansion and gas exchange.

 

An iron lung, also known as a negative pressure ventilator, is a device used to assist patients with respiratory paralysis, such as those affected by polio.

 

It works by enclosing the patient's body from the neck down within a large airtight chamber.

 

The chamber is then alternately pressurized and depressurized, creating a negative pressure around the chest and abdomen.

During negative pressure cycles, the chest expands, leading to inhalation, while relaxation of the chamber causes exhalation.

 

This approach supports the natural mechanics of breathing by promoting lung expansion and aiding gas exchange.

 

The other options - Incorrect

 

A. The iron lung uses negative pressure, not positive pressure, to assist with breathing.

 

C. While modern ventilators have advanced algorithms and monitoring, the iron lung is an older technology that does not possess such capabilities.

 

D. The iron lung does not stimulate nerves through electrical impulses but rather relies on changes in pressure to facilitate breathing.

choices.text: Same as the general population
1/16
1/8
1/4

questions.text: A healthy couple, who recently emigrated from Eastern Europe, bring their 3-year-old son to the office for evaluation of an eczematous rash. On examination, the child also shows signs of intellectual disability and gait abnormality and has a musty body odor. What is the likelihood that this couple's next child will be affected with the same disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1/4

 

 

Intellectual disability, gait or posture abnormality, eczema, and a musty body odor are signs of phenyketonuria (PKU). PKU is autosomal recessive disease caused by mutation of the gene that codes for phenylalanine hydroxylase. Because PKU is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, both healthy parents must be heterozygous carriers of the mutation. The probability that their next child will inherit the disease is:

 

P’ = probability that the mother transmits the mutant allele = 1/2

 

P” = probability that the father transmits the mutant allele = 1/2

 

The probability that a child will inherit a mutant allele from each carrier parent is equal to p’ x p” = 1/4, as these are independent events.

choices.text: Primary flow across the sphincter is unidirectional.
The lower esophageal sphincter is relaxed at the onset of a migrating motor complex in the stomach.
Blockade of the sphincteric innervation by a local anaesthetic causes the sphincter to relax.
The manometric pressure in the lumen of the sphincter is less than the pressure detected in the lumen on either side of the sphincter.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with symptoms of heartburn and regurgitation. The healthcare provider suspects dysfunction of a digestive tract sphincter and decides to examine the properties of the sphincter. Which of the following properties of a normal sphincter in the digestive tract would the examination most likely reveal?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primary flow across the sphincter is unidirectional.

 

Sphincters in the digestive tract serve to regulate the flow of contents between different compartments.

 

A key property of a normal sphincter is the unidirectional flow, meaning it allows movement in one direction and prevents backflow.

 

This property helps maintain the proper movement and containment of digestive substances.

 

The other options do not accurately reflect the properties of a normal sphincter:

 

B. The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) typically remains closed at rest to prevent gastric reflux into the esophagus. The term "migrating motor complex" usually refers to small intestine activity, not the stomach.

 

C. Blocking sphincteric innervation by a local anesthetic would likely result in sphincter relaxation, as neural signals responsible for maintaining tone would be blocked.

 

D. The manometric pressure within a sphincter should be greater than the pressure on either side to prevent reflux.

 

So, the most accurate description of a property of a normal sphincter is that primary flow across the sphincter is unidirectional (Option A).

choices.text: A – Neural tube, B – Presomite mesoderm , C - Ectoderm , D -  Somite
A – Neural tube, B – Presomite mesoderm, C - Mesoderm , D -   Somite
A – Neural tube, B – Somite , C - Ectoderm , D -  Presomite mesoderm
A – Neural tube, B – Somite , C - Mesoderm , D -  Presomite mesoderm

questions.text: Choose the correct option for below image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A – Neural tube, B – Somite , C - Ectoderm , D -  Presomite mesoderm

  • Given image is dorsal view of somites forming along the neural tube [the ectoderm has been partially removed]
  • Somites form from unsegmented presomitic paraxial mesoderm caudally and become segmented in more cranially positioned regions.

 

 

 

 

Reference: Langman, Medical embryology 13th edition , Page no. : 80

choices.text: Increased intrapulmonary shunting leading to ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
Insufficient tidal volume delivery causing alveolar collapse and reduced gas exchange.
Positive pressure ventilation causing air trapping and dynamic hyperinflation.
Impaired surfactant production resulting in decreased lung compliance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath. The patient's arterial blood gases reveal a low partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) and a high partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2). The healthcare team decides to initiate mechanical ventilation to provide respiratory support. Which of the following best explains the phenomenon of "auto-PEEP" that can occur in patients with severe COPD during mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positive pressure ventilation causing air trapping and dynamic hyperinflation.

 

"Auto-PEEP" (auto-positive end-expiratory pressure) occurs when positive pressure ventilation prevents complete exhalation, leading to air trapping in the lungs during each respiratory cycle.

 

In patients with severe COPD, airflow limitation and increased resistance impede the normal exhalation process.

 

Positive pressure applied during mechanical ventilation can lead to dynamic hyperinflation, where the volume of trapped gas increases with each breath.

 

This phenomenon can lead to overdistension of alveoli, reduced lung compliance, and worsened ventilation-perfusion matching.

 

The other options are incorrect

 

A. "Intrapulmonary shunting" refers to blood bypassing ventilated alveoli, leading to hypoxemia, but it does not explain the mechanism of auto-PEEP.

 

B. "Insufficient tidal volume delivery" can cause atelectasis due to alveolar collapse, but it does not specifically explain the phenomenon of auto-PEEP.

 

D. "Impaired surfactant production" affects lung compliance and alveolar stability, but it is not directly related to the dynamic hyperinflation observed in auto-PEEP.

choices.text: A – Purkinje layer, B - Granular layer, C - White mater, D - Piamater, E - Blood vessels, F -  Molecular layer
A - Granular layer, B - White mater, C -  Piamater , D - Blood vessels, E - Molecular layer, F – Purkinje layer
A – Molecular layer, B – Purkinje layer, C – Granular layer, D – White mater, E – Piamater, F – Blood vessels
A – Piamater, B – Purkinje layer, C – Granular layer, D – White mater, E – Molecular layer, F – Blood vessels

questions.text: Choose the correct options for given image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A – Molecular layer, B – Purkinje layer, C – Granular layer, D – White mater, E – Piamater, F – Blood vessels

 

 

 

Reference : Ross Histology Text and Atlas 6th edition , Page no. : 397

  • Given image is histological features of Cerebellum.
  • Grey mater of cerebellum has 3 layers :
  1. Molecular layer
  2. Purkinje layer
  3. Granular layer

choices.text: It measures tear breakup time after applying fluorescein dye.
It evaluates the ability of the pupil to constrict in response to light.
It measures intraocular pressure using a tonometer.
It assesses tear production by quantifying wetting of a filter paper placed in the lower eyelid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient complains of persistent dry eyes and discomfort. The ophthalmologist suspects a decreased tear production as a potential cause and decides to perform the Schirmer test to assess tear production. Which of the following statements best describes this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It assesses tear production by quantifying wetting of a filter paper placed in the lower eyelid.

 

The Schirmer test is used to assess tear production and diagnose conditions such as dry eye syndrome. During the test, a standardized filter paper strip is placed in the lower eyelid's lateral third, away from the cornea. The patient's eyes are then closed for a defined period (usually 5 minutes) to allow tear secretion to wet the filter paper.

 

The length of the wet portion of the filter paper is measured and indicates the amount of tear production.

 

The Schirmer test helps evaluate tear quantity and aids in diagnosing conditions involving decreased tear production, such as dry eye disease.

 

Other options are incorrect-

 

A. Tear breakup time is a different test used to assess tear film stability, not tear production.

 

B. Pupil constriction in response to light is assessed using the swinging flashlight test, not the Schirmer test.

 

C. Intraocular pressure is measured using a tonometer, such as the Goldmann applanation tonometer.

choices.text: Collagen cross-linking
Collagen fibril production
Collagenase synthesis
Elastin degradation

questions.text: 63-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine preventive examination. She has no significant medical problems and takes no medications. The patient consumes a balanced diet; gets regular exercise; and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or ilicit drugs. She is up to date on breast, colon, cervical, and lipid screenings. Her physical examination findings are unremarkable. The patient expresses concern about wrinkles around her eyes that make her "look old." A decrease in which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's complaint?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Collagen fibril production

 

Photoaging is a product of excess exposure to ultraviolet A wavelengths and is characterized by epidermal atrophy with flattening of rete ridges. In addition, there is decreased collagen fibril production and increased degradation of collagen and elastin in the dermis.

choices.text: Glycogen phosphorylase
Hormone-sensitive lipase
Lipoprotein lipase
Mitochondrial HMG CoA synthase

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after Iying on the floor in her home for the past 2 days. The patient's neighbor called police after phone calls were not answered and no one opened the door. She was found awake on the bathroom floor lying in feces and urine. The patient says she fell and injured her right hip and was unable to get up to call for help. She did not eat or drink anything during that time. On examination the patient appears dehydrated and has right hip tenderness. Laboratory studies show serum glucose of 72 mg/dL and positive urine ketones. Radiographs of the right hip show a right femoral neck fracture. Increased activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely contributing to both the serum and urine laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hormone-sensitive lipase

 

 

This patient's laboratory studies show the presence of ketones in the urine and maintenance of fasting blood glucose values in the low-normal range despite prolonged fasting. Hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) is an enzyme found in adipose tissue that catalyzes the mobilization of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids (FFAs) and glycerol. HSL is activated in response to stress hormones (eg, catecholamines, glucagon, ACTH), whereas it is inhibited by the release of insulin.

choices.text: Activation of acetylcholine (ACh) receptors
Suppression of hyperpolarizing after-potentials
Receptor activation of adenylyl cyclase
Hyperpolarization of the membrane potential

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with unexplained gastrointestinal symptoms, including severe constipation. An electrophysiological study of a neuron within the Enteric Nervous System (ENS) is conducted. The study reveals the presence of a fast Excitatory Postsynaptic Potential. Considering the electrophysiological findings in this patient, which of the following properties is most likely associated with the detected change?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Activation of acetylcholine (ACh) receptors

 

Fast EPSPs are typically associated with the activation of excitatory neurotransmitters like acetylcholine (ACh). In the ENS, ACh is a common neurotransmitter that stimulates smooth muscle contraction and promotes gastrointestinal motility. Therefore, the presence of a fast EPSP suggests the involvement of ACh receptors in mediating excitatory responses in the ENS, which can contribute to normal gastrointestinal function.

choices.text: 3-Hydroxy-3-methylglutaryI-CoA Iyase
Ornithine transcarbamylase
Pyruvate carboxylase
Transketolase

questions.text: As a part of a research study investigating enzymatic activity in both normal and diseased liver tissue, hepatocytes are isolated from biopsy samples obtained from patients undergoing routine care at a local tertiary referral center. The cells are homogenized and centrifuged to remove membrane components and organelles. Following subsequent rounds of centrifugation, the remaining supernatant contains only cytosol and cytosolic proteins. Activity of which of the following enzymes will most likely be detectable in the supernatant of healthy liver cells?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Transketolase

choices.text: 35 mmHg
50 mmHg
65 mmHg
80 mmHg

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes blood gas analysis as part of their diagnostic workup. The intern erroneously calculates the concentration of oxygen (O2) in the blood as 0.0025 ml/ml of blood. Considering atmospheric pressure to be 760 mmHg, what would be the approximate O2 tension (in mmHg) in the blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 80 mmHg

 

 

According to Henry’s Law

  • When pressure is expressed in atmospheric (1 atmospheric = 760 mmHg) and conc.  Is expressed in volume of gas dissolved in each volume of water, the solubility coefficient for gases at body temperature.
  • In these question
  • Conc. Of O2 in blood
    • = 0.025 ml/ml
    • = 2.5 ml/L
  • We know that normal dissolved O2 is 0.3 ml% gives a PaO2 of around 95-98 mm Hg( ~ 100 mm Hg)
  • So, 0.25ml% would give roughly 80 mm Hg.

choices.text: Dihydrobiopterin reductase
Dopamine B-hydroxylase
Phenylalanine hydroxylase
Phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase

questions.text: 1-day-old boy is diagnosed with hyperphenylalanemia by newborn screening. He is placed on a special phenylalanine-restricted diet with tyrosine supplementation. The parents are extensively counselled on the boy's condition and informed of the necessary dietary restrictions. They are also instructed to return to his physician for regular follow-up visits. Several months later, laboratory test results indicate that the infant has a normal serum phenylalanine level. Careful examination, however, reveals some neurological abnormalities, including axial hypotonia and microcephaly. Further workup is notable for elevated prolactin. What is the likely deficiency leading to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dihydrobiopterin reductase

 

Disorders involving impaired tetrahydrobiopterin (BH.) levels, the most common being dihydrobiopterin reductase deficiency, account for 2% of phenyiketonuria cases. BH4 is an important cofactor for both phenylalanine hydroxylase and tyrosine hydroxylase. Although phenylalanine levels can be corrected with dietary restriction, downstream deficiencies of dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, and serotonin lead to progressive neurologic deterioration. Dopamine deficiency leads to hyperprolactinemia in these patients.

choices.text: This is a large, triangular fusion of five vertebrae and forms the posterosuperior wall of the pelvic cavity, wedged between the two innominate bones.
Its blunted, caudal apex articulates with the coccyx and its superior, wide base with the fifth lumbar vertebra at the lumbosacral angle.
It is set obliquely and curved longitudinally, the dorsal surface is convex, and the pelvic surface is concave; this ventral curvature increases pelvic capacity.
In childhood, individual sacral vertebrae are connected by intervertebral discs, and the adult bone retains many vertebral features.

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding shown bon:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. In childhood, individual sacral vertebrae are connected by intervertebral discs, and the adult bone retains many vertebral features.

  • In image shown bone is Sacrum (superior view).
  • In childhood, individual sacral vertebrae are connected by cartilage. Hence all statements are correct except D.

 

 

 

Reference :

Gray’s Anatomy , International edition , 42nd edition , Page no. : 830

choices.text: AUG
CCA
Methylguanosine triphosphate
Poly-A

questions.text: A series of experiments are being conducted to determine the structure and function of different types of bacterial RNA. Cultures of Staphylococcus aureus are exposed to chemicals that lyse the bacterial cells, and the RNA molecules are then extracted. A specific RNA consisting of 90 nucleotides is purified for further analysis. It is found to contain high amounts of chemically modified bases such as dithydrouridine, pseudouridine, and its secondary structure arises from base pairing within the chain. Which of the following is the most likely composition of the 3'-end of this molecule?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CCA

 

Transfer RNA (tRNA) is a small, noncoding form of RNA that contains chemically modified bases (eg, dihydrouridine, ribothymidine, pseudouridine). RNA has a CCA sequence at its 3'-end that is used as a recognition sequence by proteins. The 3' terminal hydroxyl group of the CCA tail serves as the amino acid binding site.

choices.text: Shortened PR interval
QRS complex similar to that seen with left bundle-branch block
QRS complex of shortened duration
P wave following each QRS complex

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of heart arrhythmias requires temporary electronic pacing. The pacemaker lead is placed at the apex of the right ventricle, pacing the heart at a rate of 70 beats/min. Upon comparing the patient's ECG during pacing with the ECG before pacing, what specific electrocardiographic change would you anticipate, considering the site of pacing and its potential impact on cardiac conduction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. QRS complex similar to that seen with left bundle-branch block

 

When a patient receives right ventricular apex pacing, it can result in a widened QRS complex on the ECG, resembling a left bundle-branch block (LBBB) pattern. This is because the electrical depolarization of the ventricles is initiated from the apex of the right ventricle rather than the normal His-Purkinje system, leading to delayed activation of the left ventricle.

  • Option A (Shortened PR interval) would not be expected because the atria and the AV node are not affected by ventricular pacing.
  • Option C (QRS complex of shortened duration) is incorrect because pacing from the right ventricular apex typically results in a widened QRS complex.
  • Option D (P wave following each QRS complex) is not typically seen with ventricular pacing as the atria and ventricles are paced separately, and atrial activity can be dissociated from ventricular activity in this scenario.

choices.text: Nucleotide mismatches that escape repair
Covalent bonds between adjacent pyrimidines
Insertion of abnormal bases into DNA
Double strand breaks in DNA

questions.text: 34-year-old woman comes to the physician with abdominal pain and melena. She also complains of progressive fatigue and a 5 kg weight loss over the last 2 months. She has a strong family history of colon, endometrial, and ovarian cancer. Colonoscopy shows a protuberant, friable mass in the ascending colon, and biopsy is diagnostic for colon adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation consistent with Lynch syndrome. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the development of colon cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nucleotide mismatches that escape repair

 

Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease caused by abnormal nucleotide mismatch repair. The mismatch repair system involves several genes, including MSH2 and MLH1, which code for components of the human MutS and Mutl homologs. Mutations in these 2 genes account for around 90% of cases of Lynch syndrome.

choices.text: A is the largest and most superficial of the three anterolateral abdominal muscles which is attached to the external surfaces and inferior borders of the distal eight ribs.
The muscle fibres of B are usually interrupted by one to four tendinous intersections.
C is located at L3 – L4 vertebral level.
Modification of D forms inguinal ligament & lacunar ligament but not the pectineal ligament.

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient victim of a motorcycle accident was presented to the emergency room with shortness of breath, pale and unstable, with a 155 bpm, 96% O2 saturation, a blood pressure of 90 × 60 mmHg and a Glasgow score of 12. Furthermore, the patient presented a blunt abdominal trauma and advanced trauma life support (ATLS) was promptly initiated. The patient was rushed to the operating room and submitted to an exploratory laparotomy.  Incision was given in anterior abdominal wall. All of the following statements are true about the anterior abdominal wall structures except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Modification of D forms inguinal ligament & lacunar ligament but not the pectineal ligament.   

 

In image different layers of anterior abdominal wall has been shown.  Let’s break down each option:

  • Option A: A is external oblique muscle. It is the largest and most superficial of the three anterolateral abdominal muscles (EO, IO, TA) , which is attached to the external surfaces and inferior borders of the distal eight ribs. Hence it is true. 
  • Option B: B is rectus abdominis muscle, which is a paired, long, strap-like muscle that extends along the entire length of the anterior abdominal wall on either side of the linea alba . It varies widely in width and thickness from individual to individual but is generally widest in the proximal abdomen. The muscle fibres of rectus abdominis are usually interrupted by one to four fibrous bands (three being the most common) or tendinous intersections, which pass transversely or obliquely across the muscle. One is usually situated at the level of the umbilicus, another opposite the free end of the xiphoid process and the third about midway between the other two. Hence this statement is also true.
  • Option C: C is umbilicus, which is located at L3- L4 vertebral level. It is also true statement.
  • Option D: D is external oblique aponeurosis. There are 3 modifications of it :
  1. Inguinal ligament
  2. Lacunar ligament
  3. Pectineal ligament

 

It is also forming the pectineal ligament hence this statement is wrong.

 

Reference :

Gray’s Anatomy , International edition , 42nd edition , Page no. : 1126

choices.text: The artery arising from A is usually single, although up to four openings have been observed, reflecting the independent origins of the conal, sinuatrial nodal and ventricular arteries.

The artery arising from B is usually larger in calibre than the right and It supplies a greater volume of myocardium, including almost all of the right ventricle and atrium, and most of the interventricular septum.
C is ear like muscular projection arising from chamber where D is opening.
D is formed by union of right & left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: All the following are correct for given image except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The artery arising from B is usually larger in calibre than the right and It supplies a greater volume of myocardium, including almost all of the right ventricle and atrium, and most of the interventricular septum.

 

This is superior view of heart showing aortic & pulmonary valve.  Let’s break down each option:

  • Option A: A is ostium of right coronary artery,  which arises from the right aortic sinus. The artery is usually single, although up to four openings have been observed, reflecting the independent origins of the conal, sinuatrial nodal and ventricular arteries. The right coronary artery passes at first anteriorly and slightly to the right between the right atrial auricle and pulmonary trunk.

 

Hence it is true. 

  • Option B: B is osteum of left coronary artery. Left coronary artery is usually larger in calibre than the right. It supplies a greater volume of myocardium, including almost all of the left ventricle and atrium, and most of the interventricular septum While in option it is given that right ventricle and atrium which is wrong.
  • Option C: C is right auricle, which is ear like muscular projection from right atria. In image is marked D which is right atria, Hence this statement is also true.
  • Option D: D is superior venacava, which is formed by union of right & left brachiocephalic vein. That’s why it is also true statement.

 

 

 

Reference :

Gray’s Anatomy , International edition , 42nd edition , Page no. : 1091

choices.text: D
C
B
A

questions.text: A 42 years old male presented in surgery OPD with hematemesis & chronic diffuse pain in retrosternal part. He has history of smoking & alcohol past 21 years. On examination Urea breath test was found negative.  On Endoscopic examination gastric ulcer was found. According to modified Johnson’s classification it was categorized under Type IV. To prevent bleeding which of the following artery should be ligated:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. D

  • This is a case of gastric ulcer disease (GUD). It is divided into following 5 types on basis of location by Johnson:
  • Johnson’s Classification of Gastric Ulcer Disease

 

 

 

  • Given case is type IV GUD in which ulcer area is supplied by left gastric artery. That’s why we will ligate left gastric artery which is shown in image as A but has been put in option D.

 

 

 

 

 

Reference : Gray’s Anatomy , International edition , 42nd edition , Page no. : 1164

choices.text: DNA supercoil accumulation
Extensive double-strand DNA break repair
Impaired mismatch repair
Low transcription activity

questions.text: 24-year-old woman comes to the office after discovering a new mole on her right leg. She is worried that it might be skin cancer as she has been going out in the sun very frequently because of her job as a reporter. Physical examination shows a 5-mm brown, oval macule on her anterior thigh with a homogeneous coloration and discrete borders. The lesion appears darker than her other moles. A biopsy of the lesion shows normal-appearing nevus cells clustered in the epidermis, and she is diagnosed with a benign acquired melanocytic nevus. During histologic analysis, her epithelial cells are each found to contain a condensed body composed of heavily methylated DNA at the periphery of the nucleus. This region of DNA is most likely associated with which of the following genetic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Low transcription activity

 

X-inactivation occurs in genetically normal females and results in conversion of the inactivated X chromosome into compact heterochromatin (Barr body). Heterochromatin is condensed chromatin composed of heavily methylated DNA in tight association with deacetylated histones. It has a low level of transcriptional activity. In contrast, euchromatin is loosely arranged and exhibits a high level of transcriptional activity.

choices.text: DNA ligase
Endonuclease
Helicase
Topoisomerase

questions.text: 6-year-old boy is brought to the office due to a persistent facial ulcer for the past 2 months. His mother reports that the patient has extreme sensitivity to sunlight and has developed freckles on his face, neck, and limbs since infancy. On physical examination, the skin in sun-exposed areas is dry and rough with numerous freckles and erythematous macules. There is an ulcerated plaque on the left face; a biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma. Further testing leads to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. A defect in which of the following enzymes is most likely causing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endonuclease

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defective nucleotide excision repair often caused by a deficiency in UV-specific endonuclease. Affected children usually have severe photosensitivity, hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas, and a greatly increased risk for skin cancer.
